input.status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):work in progress by Flo Hodkiewicz

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem: PH1a  Chiller 8C Has a fan fault (hi dc). This has limited the chiller unit working to it's potential putting extra strain on the secondary unit.
scope_of_work.scope:
specialist contractor to attend site, and isolate chiller 8C, disconnect faulty fan and remove.
they will then install new fan, re-connect and program. Chiller 8C will then be tested to prove it operates as it should.
scope_of_work.justification:
If Chiller 8C's faulty fan is not replaced this could result in the extra strain on the unit  failing, leaving us with the chiller out of service, which will then lead to the extra loads moving on to the remaining chillers and creating extra strain upon them.
this could then lead to the resilience of PH1a  being compromised
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect:
If Chiller 8C's faulty fan is not replaced this could result in the extra strain on the unit  failing, leaving us with the chiller out of service, which will then lead to the extra loads moving on to the remaining chillers and creating extra strain upon them.
this could then lead to the resilience of PH1a  being compromised

input.project_name: UPM-Relocation of CCTV Rack from CSN to CSSE
input.status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):work in progress by Brando Dooley DDS

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
4. This is purely for a survey of the area, a Proposal/quotation will follow this with LSQ to detail the works/cost involved of the physical move of the rack
scope_of_work.problem: Perform a survey to relocate CCTV  rack from CSN to CSSE,  this will enable energy savings and allow CSN to be mothballed.
scope_of_work.scope: Ajartec CCTV engineer to attend site to perform a survey which will enable them to draw up a proposal/quote for the task of moving the CCTV rack from CSN to CSSE.
scope_of_work.justification: Cost saving relocating the  rack from CSN to CSSE this enables the cooling to be turned off and CSN to mothballed.  This spend is for Ajartec to perform a survey to move the CCTV rack to across the corridor to CSSE. A quotation will follow from this survey for the relocation works
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: Non approval will lead to higher running costs for cooling CSN, CSN can then not be mothballed.

input.status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):billing completed by Marge Hills (2):offer submitted by Marge Hills

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem: The access corridor to the data centre is looking dated with paintwork peeling off and generally in a poor condition.
scope_of_work.scope:
Decoration Works:
•	Provide a temporary screen to segregate the half of the corridor being worked on at the time.
•	Provide temporary flooring protection for the duration of the works in the form of Correx sheeting.
•	Clean all existing aluminium glazing bars supporting glass panels.
•	Prepare and paint all existing white structural steelwork with 3 full coats of Rustoleum Noxyde Pegacrl in white.
•	Paint all shadow baton in black eggshell.
•	Supply all required access equipment to complete the works detailed in this document.
•	Remove all waste created by these works from site.
•	Supply as part of final handover an O&M manual detailing all materials used.
scope_of_work.justification: This is the main entrance to the data centre and provides the first impression for new and existing clients, this area is not up to the standards expected and required of a data centre entrance. If left indefinitely structural problems will begin to occur with corrosion setting in.
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: This area will remain in a poor condition leading to poor first impressions of the data centre. Structural problems could eventually occur.

input.project_name: UPM-Coil chemical clean and Installation of condenser coil screens on 4 x York Chillers
input.status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):work in progress by Brando Dooley DDS

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem: Due to high levels of pollen and airborne debris, dirt has built up on the chiller condenser coils and hardened leading to a reduced ability to transfer heat to the outside air and a less effective cooling system.
scope_of_work.scope: 3rd Party contractor to attend site carry out a chemical clean on the chiller coils, clean the frame and structure of the chiller and fit the air flow screens to the four York chillers.
scope_of_work.justification: Fitting the screens will prevent pollen, insects and other airborne debris from clogging the condenser coils, saving on future repairs and energy as optimum airflow will be maintained.
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: Dirty coils reduce airflow, decrease heat exchanger efficiency, and reduce air conditioning system capacity. In addition, dirty coils contribute to poor air quality and are a major cause of compressor and condenser fan motor failures in chiller systems, leading to costly repair works.

input.associated_items: the assositated items with their boolean values are mentioned: As Builts (Yes), EANS/CMMS Update (Yes), O&M Manuals (Yes), Job Punch List (Yes), Health & Safety Form (EPIC Form) (Yes), Single Source Approval (Yes), Close-Out Checklist (Yes)

input.project_name: UPM-Cooling Tower 1A - Complete single fan replacement
input.status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):work in progress by Flo Hodkiewicz

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem: The cooling towers have 3 fan sections in total with 2 fans on each section. On Cooling tower 1A the bearings on the single fan section blade have broken down. If this fan fails the tower will have to be shut down until repaired. If we do not carry out the works it could result in the resilience of phase 1 site cooling to be at risk
scope_of_work.scope:
•	Tower will receive a pre-disinfection dose directly to the tower sump -0.5 litres of both ABT1 & ABT2. Tower pre-disinfection will be for 1 hour, minimum 
•	ABT1 & ABT2 levels are to be monitored and logged on the service report sheet. When an acceptable level has been achieved, these details are also recorded on the dynamic risk assessment service report sheet
•	CBRE with Baltimore Air Coil technicians in attendance will then make the necessary electrical isolations as per the approved FSP
•	CBRE with Baltimore Air Coil technicians in attendance will manually isolate the flow and return water valves positioned on the tower sump and on the return pipework on the top inspection platform. CBRE with WCS Group technicians in attendance will also isolate the Mains Water inlet valve to stop tower from filling
•	The Tower will then be drained to the dedicated foul drain using the drain off valve and sump pump
•	The faulty fan will then be stripped down and replaced with new fan shafts and bearings.
•	On completion of the fan repair, the other 2 fans on cooling tower 1A will be inspected for damage and where necessary, advise replacement.
•	After repair to the fan has been completed on the tower, Baltimore Air Coil technicians will, where applied, remove their locks and clasps and CBRE will run the fans and make sure all is ok. Once happy the tower shall be filled back to it’s appropriate levels.
•	The circulating water will be tested for bromine, ABT1 and ABT2 will be added to boost the level above 100ppm, the bromine level will be monitored every 15 minutes
•	Once acceptable the tower will be dosed with commissioning dose of inhibitor
•	On completion of the Tower post-disinfection CBRE will be informed so we can reinstate the electrical supply to the fans and pumps then sign off the permit to work relating to the Tower
scope_of_work.justification: If Cooling Tower 1A - single fan is not replaced this could impact the resilience of cooling for phase 1
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: If Cooling Tower 1A - single fan is not replaced this could impact the resilience of cooling for phase 1

The problem statement indicates: The cooling towers have 3 fan sections in total with 2 fans on each section. On Cooling tower 1A the bearings on the single fan section blade have broken down. If this fan fails the tower will have to be shut down until repaired. If we do not carry out the works it could result in the resilience of phase 1 site cooling to be at risk. The defined scope of work includes: •	Tower will receive a pre-disinfection dose directly to the tower sump -0.5 litres of both ABT1 & ABT2. Tower pre-disinfection will be for 1 hour, minimum 
•	ABT1 & ABT2 levels are to be monitored and logged on the service report sheet. When an acceptable level has been achieved, these details are also recorded on the dynamic risk assessment service report sheet
•	CBRE with Baltimore Air Coil technicians in attendance will then make the necessary electrical isolations as per the approved FSP
•	CBRE with Baltimore Air Coil technicians in attendance will manually isolate the flow and return water valves positioned on the tower sump and on the return pipework on the top inspection platform. CBRE with WCS Group technicians in attendance will also isolate the Mains Water inlet valve to stop tower from filling
•	The Tower will then be drained to the dedicated foul drain using the drain off valve and sump pump
•	The faulty fan will then be stripped down and replaced with new fan shafts and bearings.
•	On completion of the fan repair, the other 2 fans on cooling tower 1A will be inspected for damage and where necessary, advise replacement.
•	After repair to the fan has been completed on the tower, Baltimore Air Coil technicians will, where applied, remove their locks and clasps and CBRE will run the fans and make sure all is ok. Once happy the tower shall be filled back to it’s appropriate levels.
•	The circulating water will be tested for bromine, ABT1 and ABT2 will be added to boost the level above 100ppm, the bromine level will be monitored every 15 minutes
•	Once acceptable the tower will be dosed with commissioning dose of inhibitor
•	On completion of the Tower post-disinfection CBRE will be informed so we can reinstate the electrical supply to the fans and pumps then sign off the permit to work relating to the Tower. The justification provided is: If Cooling Tower 1A - single fan is not replaced this could impact the resilience of cooling for phase 1.
